info.game_comments:
2001 College Championship quarterfinal game 5.
From the campus at UCLA.

(Jimmy: [Austrian accent] I'm Jimmy of the Clue Crew.  Flex your mental muscle.  We're here to pump... [claps] you up... next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: A major New York City airport

(2, 1).clue: 25 miles north of Terre Haute in this state, you'll find Parke County, the Covered Bridge Capital of the World

(3, 1).clue: The world headquarters for this religion is in Salt Lake City, Utah

(4, 1).clue: Guinness lists the official altitude record for this soaring sport as 14,250.69 feet

(5, 1).clue: Colorful images in this patriotic classic include "purple mountain majesties" & "amber waves of grain"

(6, 1).clue: In a 1961 Joseph Heller novel, "There was only one catch and that was" this

(2, 2).clue: Most cities would cringe, but Hidalgo in this U.S. state embraced being the Killer Bee Capital

(3, 2).clue: This sacred text contains the revelations of Allah to the Prophet Muhammad

(4, 2).clue: A woman from Cyprus spent a record 6 days trapped in one of these, & probably without muzak

(5, 2).clue: This anthem is sung to the tune of the old drinking song "To Anacreon In Heaven"

(6, 2).clue: The narrator of his "Remembrance of Things Past" is named Marcel

(1, 3).clue: North American team sport played with a netted stick

(2, 3).clue: A killer place to visit is the Shark's Tooth Capital of the world in Sarasota County in this state

(3, 3).clue: During religious services, Jewish boys & men traditionally wear these skullcaps

(4, 3).clue: This 70-something actor is listed as the oldest racing driver

(5, 3).clue: Kate Smith blessed the world with the first public rendition of this Irving Berlin song in 1938

(6, 3).clue: The 8,000-copy first printing of this 1967 Gabriel Garcia Marquez novel sold out in a week

(2, 4).clue: Miss USA, not Al Gore, was grand marshal at this state's Mule-lennium Party in Columbia, the Mule Capital

(3, 4).clue: This form of Buddhism developed in China in the 500s, then later spread to Japan

(4, 4).clue: Someone get this man a burger!  He's starred in more TV ads than any other company founder

(5, 4).clue: Originally released in 1984, this Lee Greenwood crowd pleaser is back on the charts in 2001

(6, 4).clue: This Catherine Marshall novel became a TV series with Kellie Martin teaching in the Appalachians

(2, 5).clue: Vidalia is not only this state's official vegetable but the city that's the Sweet Onion Capital of the World

(3, 5).clue: During a visit to Connecticut in 1741 he delivered his "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God" sermon

(4, 5).clue: Using dishwashing liquid, glycerol, water & a wand, Alan McKay created one of these 105 feet long

(5, 5).clue: Written by clergyman Samuel Smith, this "country" song has the same melody as "God Save The Queen"

(6, 5).clue: This E. Annie Proulx novel gives the "News" on Quoyle, a sad man with a huge chin

(1, 1).clue: This over 20-mile-long boulevard has great views of the daily event it's named for

(2, 1).clue: Dear Pindar, good news: when this Macedonian sacked Thebes in 335 B.C., I hear he spared your house

(3, 1).clue: It's the TV cable network that presents "Divas Live"

(4, 1).clue: This author of "Roughing It" was born on November 30, 1835

(5, 1).clue: All was not well in Beantown when Billy, played by Gil Bellows, died of a brain hemorrhage on this Kelley show

(6, 1).clue: All is well if things are on an "even" one of these

(1, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew bench presses... with a little help.)  I'm doing some reps at this beach in Venice where Hulk Hogan & Schwarzenegger pumped up

(2, 2).clue: Good news, Praxiteles!  Copies of your statue of this kind of part-goat guy... I can't keep 'em in stock

(3, 2).clue: While today's pool balls are made of plastic, they used to be made from this valuable substance

(4, 2).clue: In Great Britain, every November 5 is his "Day", celebrated with fireworks & bonfires

(5, 2).clue: All was not well in Beantown when D.A. Richard Bay was gunned down in his car on this ABC drama

(6, 2).clue: "Batten down" these to prepare for trouble

(1, 3).clue: "First thing you know, ol' Jed's a millionaire, kinfolk said, Jed, move away from there" to this city (in song, that is)

(2, 3).clue: Dear Xenophon, I couldn't put down your book "Memorabilia" about this philosopher & his conversations

(3, 3).clue: Among this state university's songs are "A Hymn To Queens" & "In A Quaint Old Jersey Town"

(4, 3).clue: On Nov. 28, 1520 this explorer & his ships entered the Pacific Ocean, which he named for its calmness

(5, 3).clue: All was not well in Beantown when teacher Harry Senate couldn't save a gangbanger from his fate on this show

(6, 3).clue: "To take" this "out of someone's sails" is to make him halt his activity

(1, 4).clue: In 1989 Martin Sheen, honorary mayor of this beach city, home of Pepperdine U., declared it a nuclear-free zone

(2, 4).clue: Hey guy!  Aristophanes sure satirized you in "The Frogs"; it was much funnier than your "Medea"

(3, 4).clue: A cavalry horse named Comanche who survived this 1876 battle is preserved & displayed at a museum in Kansas

(4, 4).clue: On Nov. 10, 1994 this Mideast king made his first official visit to Israel

(5, 4).clue: After getting shot by a gang member, there was no more hope on this medical drama for Alan Birch

(6, 4).clue: "Lower" this on someone when it's time to make him pay

(1, 5).clue: This venue, home to the first Super Bowl, was also the site of the 1932 & 1984 Olympic games

(2, 5).clue: Dear Aristeides, I can't believe this author paralleled your life with that Roman loser Marcus Cato

(3, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from Central Park.)  Some people think Mother Goose was inspired by Queen Goosefoot, the mother of this King of the Franks

(4, 5).clue: The Continental Congress adopted these on Nov. 15, 1777 & submitted them to the states for ratification

(5, 5).clue: Spontaneous combustion claimed the mayor of Rome, Wi. on this drama with Ray Walston as Judge Bone

(6, 5).clue: Someone who's a "loose" one of these can be unpredictable trouble in the making

(0, 0).clue: First & last names of the 2 First Ladies who each had a husband & son serve as president
